line: Deep Neural Networks for Object Detection
label: heading

line: Christian Szegedy Alexander Toshev Dumitru Erhan
label: heading

line: Google, Inc.
label: paragraph

line: {szegedy, toshev, dumitru}@google.com
label: paragraph

line: Abstract
label: heading

line: Deep Neural Networks (DNNs) have recently shown outstanding performance on
label: paragraph

line: image classiﬁcation tasks [14]. In this paper we go one step further and address
label: paragraph

line: the problem of object detection using DNNs, that is not only classifying but also
label: paragraph

line: precisely localizing objects of various classes. We present a simple and yet pow-
label: paragraph

line: erful formulation of object detection as a regression problem to object bounding
label: paragraph

line: box masks. We deﬁne a multi-scale inference procedure which is able to pro-
label: paragraph

line: duce high-resolution object detections at a low cost by a few network applications.
label: paragraph

line: State-of-the-art performance of the approach is shown on Pascal VOC.
label: paragraph

line: 1 Introduction
label: heading

line: As we move towards more complete image understanding, having more precise and detailed object
label: paragraph

line: recognition becomes crucial. In this context, one cares not only about classifying images, but also
label: paragraph

line: about precisely estimating estimating the class and location of objects contained within the images,
label: paragraph

line: a problem known as object detection.
label: paragraph

line: The main advances in object detection were achieved thanks to improvements in object representa-
label: paragraph

line: tions and machine learning models. A prominent example of a state-of-the-art detection system is
label: paragraph

line: the Deformable Part-based Model (DPM) [9]. It builds on carefully designed representations and
label: paragraph

line: kinematically inspired part decompositions of objects, expressed as a graphical model. Using dis-
label: paragraph

line: criminative learning of graphical models allows for building high-precision part-based models for
label: paragraph

line: variety of object classes.
label: paragraph

line: Manually engineered representations in conjunction with shallow discriminatively trained models
label: paragraph

line: have been among the best performing paradigms for the related problem of object classiﬁcation
label: paragraph

line: as well [17]. In the last years, however, Deep Neural Networks (DNNs) [12] have emerged as a
label: paragraph

line: powerful machine learning model.
label: paragraph

line: DNNs exhibit major differences from traditional approaches for classiﬁcation. First, they are deep
label: paragraph

line: architectures which have the capacity to learn more complex models than shallow ones [2]. This
label: paragraph

line: expressivity and robust training algorithms allow for learning powerful object representations with-
label: paragraph

line: out the need to hand design features. This has been empirically demonstrated on the challenging
label: paragraph

line: ImageNet classiﬁcation task [5] across thousands of classes [14, 15].
label: paragraph

line: In this paper, we exploit the power of DNNs for the problem of object detection, where we not only
label: paragraph

line: classify but also try to precisely localize objects. The problem we are address here is challenging,
label: paragraph

line: since we want to detect a potentially large number object instances with varying sizes in the same
label: paragraph

line: image using a limited amount of computing resources.
label: paragraph

line: We present a formulation which is capable of predicting the bounding boxes of multiple objects in
label: paragraph

line: a given image. More precisely, we formulate a DNN-based regression which outputs a binary mask
label: paragraph

line: of the object bounding box (and portions of the box as well), as shown in Fig. 1. Additionally,
label: paragraph

line: we employ a simple bounding box inference to extract detections from the masks. To increase
label: paragraph

line: localization precision, we apply the DNN mask generation in a multi-scale fashion on the full image
label: paragraph

line: as well as on a small number of large image crops, followed by a reﬁnement step (see Fig. 2).
label: paragraph

line: In this way, only through a few dozen DNN-regressions we can achieve state-of-art bounding box
label: paragraph

line: localization.
label: paragraph

line: In this paper, we demonstrate that DNN-based regression is capable of learning features which
label: paragraph

line: are not only good for classiﬁcation, but also capture strong geometric information. We use the
label: paragraph

line: general architecture introduced for classiﬁcation by [14] and replace the last layer with a regression
label: paragraph

line: layer. The somewhat surprising but powerful insight is that networks which to some extent encode
label: paragraph

line: translation invariance, can capture object locations as well.
label: paragraph

line: Second, we introduce a multi-scale box inference followed by a reﬁnement step to produce precise
label: paragraph

line: detections. In this way, we are able to apply a DNN which predicts a low-resolution mask, limited
label: paragraph

line: by the output layer size, to pixel-wise precision at a low cost – the network is a applied only a few
label: paragraph

line: dozen times per input image.
label: paragraph

line: In addition, the presented method is quite simple. There is no need to hand design a model which
label: paragraph

line: captures parts and their relations explicitly. This simplicity has the advantage of easy applicability
label: paragraph

line: to wide range of classes, but also show better detection performance across a wider range of objects
label: paragraph

line: rigid ones as well as deformable ones. This is presented together with state-of-the-art detection
label: paragraph

line: results on Pascal VOC challenge [7] in Sec. 7.
label: paragraph

line: 2 Related Work
label: heading

line: One of the most heavily studied paradigms for object detection is the deformable part-based model,
label: paragraph

line: with [9] being the most prominent example. This method combines a set of discriminatively trained
label: paragraph

line: parts in a star model called pictorial structure. It can be considered as a 2-layer model – parts being
label: paragraph

line: the ﬁrst layer and the star model being the second layer. Contrary to DNNs, whose layers are generic,
label: paragraph

line: the work by [9] exploits domain knowledge – the parts are based on manually designed Histogram
label: paragraph

line: of Gradients (HOG) descriptors [4] and the structure of the parts is kinematically motivated.
label: paragraph

line: Deep architectures for object detection and parsing have been motivated by part-based models and
label: paragraph

line: traditionally are called compositional models, where the object is expressed as layered composition
label: paragraph

line: of image primitives. A notable example is the And/Or graph [20], where an object is modeled
label: paragraph

line: by a tree with And-nodes representing different parts and Or-nodes representing different modes
label: paragraph

line: of the same part. Similarly to DNNs, the And/Or graph consists of multiple layers, where lower
label: paragraph

line: layers represent small generic image primitives, while higher layers represent object parts. Such
label: paragraph

line: compositional models are easier to interpret than DNNs. On the other hand, they require inference
label: paragraph

line: while the DNN models considered in this paper are purely feed-forward with no latent variables to
label: paragraph

line: be inferred.
label: paragraph

line: Further examples of compositional models for detection are based on segments as primitives [1],
label: paragraph

line: focus on shape [13], use Gabor ﬁlters [10] or larger HOG ﬁlters [19]. These approaches are tra-
label: paragraph

line: ditionally challenged by the difﬁculty of training and use specially designed learning procedures.
label: paragraph

line: Moreover, at inference time they combine bottom-up and top-down processes.
label: paragraph

line: Neural networks (NNs) can be considered as compositional models where the nodes are more
label: paragraph

line: generic and less interpretable than the above models. Applications of NNs to vision problems are
label: paragraph

line: decades old, with Convolutional NNs being the most prominent example [16]. It was not until
label: paragraph

line: recently than these models emerged as highly successful on large-scale image classiﬁcation tasks
label: paragraph

line: [14, 15] in the form of DNNs. Their application to detection, however, is limited. Scene parsing,
label: paragraph

line: as a more detailed form of detection, has been attempted using multi-layer Convolutional NNs [8].
label: paragraph

line: Segmentation of medical imagery has been addressed using DNNs [3]. Both approaches, however,
label: paragraph

line: use the NNs as local or semi-local classiﬁers either over superpixels or at each pixel location. Our
label: paragraph

line: approach, however, uses the full image as an input and performs localization through regression. As
label: paragraph

line: such, it is a more efﬁcient application of NNs.
label: paragraph

line: Perhaps the closest approach to ours is [18] which has similar high level objective but use much
label: paragraph

line: smaller network with a different features, loss function and without a machinery to distinguish be-
label: paragraph

line: tween multiple instances of the same class.
label: paragraph
